Ron,
Very nice koshirae.  Are the plant designs etched or inlaid?  Also, does it have a normal kurikata, or a ring?

Jim



  Rich:

  I am interested, too. I don't have much to add, other than pics of 
  one I own:
  http://www.nihontophile.com/ArP1.jpg
  http://www.nihontophile.com/ArP2.jpg
  http://www.nihontophile.com/ArP3.jpg
  http://www.nihontophile.com/ArP4.jpg
  Late Koto/early Edo in late Shinshinto koshirae (with interesting 
  lock)
  Signed "Shimosaka", traditionally made (visible hada/hamon/hataraki)

  Regards,
  Ron P.

  --- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@w...> 
  wrote:
  > Greetings all, I thought I would run this by the group since its 
  been a
  > bit ( read lot ) quite out there. A mate and I were talkin swod 
  tok the
  > other night and we were discussing tanto. He mentioned and sent 
  pics of
  > a very small blade that measures app 22cm in total length. As it 
  turns
  > out, I have one almost identical in size. Mine, as is his is also 
  quite
  > thick, both about 7 or 8 mm at the munemachi, very much like a
  > yorio-doshi only far too short.
  > 
  > Paul mentioned that he was told his was made as a gift for the 
  wife of a
  > samurai as a wedding present. He believes his to be mid/late edo 
  and
  > traditionally made. MIne is out of polish and hard to see hada or 
  hamon,
  > nie, nioi etc.. but the rest of it looks pretty similar.
  > 
  > here is a link to the two tanto Tantos 
  <www.whiz.com.au/richard/tantos.jpg>
  > 
  > I believe blades were common gifts for samurai wife's and I would 
  expect
  > them to be smaller than usual but 22 cm is pretty small and more 
  like a
  > child's size, though I guess weilded properly, could inflict just 
  as
  > much damage as a 30cm tanto.
  > 
  > looking forward to all opinions.
  > 
  > cheers
  > 
  > Rich
  >
